revision.text:
{{context|date=May 2014}} '''Standard components''' is a [[food technology]] term, when manufacturers buy in a standard component they would use a pre-made product in the production of their food. They help products to be the same in consistency, they are quick and easy to use in batch production of food products. Some examples are pre-made [[stock]] cubes, [[marzipan]], icing, ready made pastry.
==Usage== Manufacturers use standard components as they save time and sometimes cost a lot less and it also helps with consistency in products. If a manufacturer is to use a standard component from another supplier it is essential that a precise and accurate specification is produced by the manufacturer so that the component meets the standards set by the manufacturer.
===Advantages===
*Saves preparation time. *Fewer steps in the production process *Less effort and skill required by staff *Less machinery and equipment needed *Good quality *Saves money from all aspects *Can be bought in bulk *High-quality consistency *Food preparation is hygienic
===Disadvantages=== *Can be expensive *Have to rely on other manufacturers to supply products *Fresh ingredients may taste better *May require special storage conditions *Less reliable than doing it yourself *Cost more to make *Can't control the nutritional value of the product *There is a larger risk of cross contamination. <!--Verify this information from CPG revision guide for [[GCSE]] Food Technology.-->
==References== {{portal|Food}} {{reflist}} *''Food Technology'' Nelson Thornes, 2001 pg. 144
[[Category:Components]] [[Category:Food industry]] [[Category:Food ingredients]]
{{ingredient-stub}}

{{Infobox company | name = Steelcase Inc. | logo = Steelcase logo.svg | native_name_lang = | former_name = Metal Office Furniture Company | type = [[Public company|Public]] | traded_as ={{NYSE|SCS}} (Class A)
[[Russell 2000 Index|Russell 2000 Component]] | industry = [[Furniture]] | founded = {{start date|1912|03|16}} in [[Grand Rapids]], [[Michigan]], United States | founders =Peter M. Wege, Walter D. Idema, David D. Hunting | hq_location_city = Grand Rapids, Michigan | hq_location_country = United States | num_locations = 80 | num_locations_year = 2014 | area_served =Worldwide | key_people = James Keane CEO | products = Office furniture, architectural and technology for office environments and the education, health care and retail industries | brands = | services = | revenue = [[United States dollar|US$]] 3.1 Billion (2015) | num_employees = 11,000 | num_employees_year = 2014 | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.steelcase.com/ steelcase.com] | footnotes = }} '''[[Steelcase]]''' is a [[United States]]-based furniture company founded in 1912 in [[Grand Rapids, Michigan]]. The company produces office furniture, architectural and technology products for [[office]] environments and the [[Higher education|education]], [[Health care industry|health care]] and [[retail]] industries. It is the largest office furniture manufacturer in the world. It has facilities, offices, and factories in the Americas, Europe, Asia, the Middle East, Australia and Africa. ==History== [[Image:Steelcase Pyramid 2008.png|thumb|upright=1.3|The Steelcase Corporate Development Center near Grand Rapids, Michigan: opened in 1989 at a cost of $111 million, vacated by Steelcase in 2010, sold for $7.5 million in 2014 — and as of 2016, sold to [[Switch (company)|Switch]] as a datacenter.
{{Coord|42.8523|N|85.5603|W|}}]] Steelcase was founded as the Metal Office Furniture Company in 1912 by Peter M. Wege in Grand Rapids, Michigan. Wege was a veteran of the [[sheet metal]] and [[fireproofing]] industry and had filed approximately 25 [[patent]]s prior to starting the company. The Metal Office Furniture Company's first products included fireproof metal [[safe]]s and four-drawer [[filing cabinet]]s, which Wege invented and manufactured for the Macey Company.{{cite book |title=Peter Martin Wege: A Biography |author=Susan Lovell |authorlink= |year=2003 |publisher=Generations Publishing |location=Pontiac, Michigan |isbn= |page= |pages=21–29 |url= |accessdate=11 October 2014}} [[File:Victor-Wastebasket.png|thumb|left|Victor wastebasket]] In 1914, the company received its first product patent for "The Victor," a fireproof steel wastebasket. The Victor gained popularity due to its light weight—achieved through a patented process of bending flat steel at right angles to create boxes—and its ability to prevent fires at a time when [[smoking]] was common indoors, particularly in the workplace.{{cite news |title=Steelcase Turns 100 |author= |url=http://www.architectmagazine.com/furniture/steelcase-anniversary.aspx |work=[[Architecture (magazine)|Architecture]] |date=March 29, 2012 |accessdate=11 October 2014}}{{cite news |title=100 Years & Building:Steelcase CEO Guides Vision for Future |author=Karen Dybis |url=http://www.corpmagazine.com/features/cover-stories/100-years-buildingsteelcase-ceo-guides-vision-for-future/ |work=Corp! Magazine |date=August 2012 |accessdate=11 October 2014}} In 1915, the company began manufacturing and distributing steel desks after designing and producing 200 for Boston's first skyscraper, the [[Custom House Tower]]. In 1937, the company collaborated with [[Frank Lloyd Wright]] on office furniture for the [[Johnson Wax Headquarters]]. The partnership lasted two years and resulted in some of the first modern workstations.{{cite news |title=Unlikely early product among 10 notable moments in Steelcase history (Steelcase at 100) |author=Jim Harger |url=http://www.mlive.com/business/west-michigan/index.ssf/2012/03/from_a_metal_waste_basket_to_g.html |work=[[MLive Media Group|MLive]] |date=March 13, 2012 |accessdate=11 October 2014}} The name Steelcase was a result of an advertising campaign to promote metal office furniture over wood and was [[trademark]]ed in 1921.{{cite web |url=http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/history2/45/Steelcase-Inc.html |title=Steelcase, Inc. - Company Profile, Information, Business Description, History, Background Information on Steelcase, Inc. |author= |date=1998 |work=referenceforbusiness.com |publisher=Reference for Business |accessdate=11 October 2014}} The company officially changed its name to Steelcase, Inc. in 1954. [[File:1977-Series-90001.png|thumb|left|300px|1977 Series 90001]] The company became known as the leader of the furniture industry in the late 1960s due to the volume of its sales.{{cite news |title=100 Years of Innovation Timeline |author= |url=http://www.steelcase.com/en/company/100-year/documents/metropolis_steelcase_special%20edition.pdf |work=[[Metropolis (architecture magazine)|Metropolis]] |date=April 2012 |accessdate=11 October 2014}} Steelcase expanded into new markets during the 1970s, including [[Asia]], [[Europe]], and [[North Africa]]. In 1973, the company debuted the Series 9000 furniture line, an [[Systems furniture|office system]] that became a best seller and the company's flagship brand.{{cite news |title=Teaching Steelcase to Dance |author=Margery B. Stein |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/01/magazine/teaching-steelcase-to-dance.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 1, 1990 |accessdate=11 October 2014}}{{cite news |title=Hudson firm taking bite out of competition |author=Andi Esposito |work=[[Worcester Telegram & Gazette]] |date=July 25, 1999 }} That same year, the company delivered the largest single furniture shipment to the then-new [[Sears Tower]]. The delivery included 43,565 pieces of furniture and furnished 44 floors. During the 1980s and 1990s, Steelcase shifted its approach to designing and creating products in response to changes in the workplace and economy. The company also focused on creativity and internal innovation by working closely with architects and interior designers to develop products as well the company's own workspace in Grand Rapids. The company's current headquarters were built in 1983 on 901 44th St. SE in Grand Rapids, Michigan. In 1989, Steelcase opened the pyramid-shaped Steelcase Inc. Corporate Development Center. The center contained ten research laboratories and workspaces meant to encourage [[Interdisciplinarity|interdisciplinary]] collaboration on [[New product development|product development]]. Steelcase vacated the Pyramid in 2010, and the Pyramid was sold to [[Switch (company)]] in 2016.{{Cite news|url=https://www.mlive.com/business/west-michigan/index.ssf/2017/03/switch_opens_most_advanced_dat.html|title=Switch opens 'most advanced data campus' in former Steelcase pyramid|work=MLive.com|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en-US}} In 1996, Steelcase became the majority stakeholder in design firm [[IDEO]] and the firm's CEO, [[David M. Kelley]], became Steelcase's vice president of technical discovery and innovation.{{cite press release |title=Steelcase, IDEO Ally; Kelley Named Steelcase VP |url=http://ir.steelcase.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=371986 |publisher=Steelcase |date=January 15, 1996 |accessdate=11 October 2014}}{{cite news |author=Bruce Nussbaum |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/bw/stories/2004-05-16/the-power-of-design |title=The Power of Design |publisher=[[BusinessWeek]] |date=May 17, 2004 |accessdate=11 October 2014}} Steelcase sold its shares back to IDEO's managers starting in 2007.{{cite news |author= Julia Bauer|url=http://blog.mlive.com/grpress/2007/09/steelcase_sees_42_percent_jump.html |title=Steelcase's IDEO will be sold over next five years |publisher=Grand Rapids Press |date=September 20, 2007 |accessdate=8 January 2015}} [[File:Multiple-15-Desk.png|thumb|right|Multiple 15 desk]] In 1996, Steelcase was found at fault in a [[patent infringement]] suit brought against them by [[Haworth (company)|Haworth, Inc.]], another furniture company. Steelcase was ordered to pay $211.5 million in damages and interest, thus ending a 17-year dispute with Haworth.{{cite news |title=$211.5 Million Award in Patent Lawsuit |author= |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/31/business/211.5-million-award-in-patent-lawsuit.html|work=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 31, 1996 |accessdate=11 October 2014}} Steelcase became a [[Public company|publicly traded company]] in 1998 under the symbol SCS. During the 2000s, Steelcase reorganized its workforce and began integrating modern technologies in its products.{{cite news |title=Steelcase CEO Jim Hackett leaves 'remarkable' tenure at retirement |author=Shandra Martinez |url=http://www.mlive.com/business/west-michigan/index.ssf/2014/01/steelcase_ceo_jim_hacketts_rem.html#comments |work=[[MLive Media Group|MLive]] |date=January 19, 2014 |accessdate=7 November 2014}} In 2000, the company opened Steelcase University, a center for ongoing employee development and learning.{{cite news |title=Learning Has a Seat at the Table |author=Jennifer J. Salopek |url=http://feature-mobile.astd.org/Publications/Magazines/TD/TD-Archive/2011/10/Learning-Has-a-Seat-at-the-Table |work=[[T+D]] |date=October 2011 |accessdate=11 October 2014}} Steelcase's wood furniture plant in Caledonia, MI earned [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] certification in 2001, becoming the first plant to receive the certification.{{cite news |title=Green Industrial |author=Jennifer Caterino |url=http://www.architectmagazine.com/industrial-projects/green-industrial.aspx |work=Architect |date=December 20, 2010 |accessdate=11 October 2014}} In 2002, Steelcase partnered with [[IBM]] to create BlueSpace, a "smart office" prototype designed using new office technologies.{{cite news |title=New Economy; I.B.M. and Steelcase lay out their vision of the office of the future. |author=Claudia H. Deutsch |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/01/14/business/new-economy-ibm-and-steelcase-lay-out-their-vision-of-the-office-of-the-future.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=January 14, 2002 |accessdate=7 November 2014}} In 2010, Steelcase and IDEO launched new models for [[higher education]] classrooms called LearnLabs.{{cite news |title=How Steelcase Redesigned the 21st Century College Classroom |author=Kaomi Goetz |url=http://www.fastcodesign.com/1662898/how-steelcase-redesigned-the-21st-century-college-classroom |work=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]] |date=December 16, 2010 |accessdate=7 November 2014}} ==Company overview== Steelcase is a [[Public company|publicly traded]] [[furniture]] manufacturer headquartered in Grand Rapids, Michigan.{{cite web |url=http://www.hoovers.com/company-information/cs/company-profile.STEELCASE_INC.a9f4f0aea860f527.html |title=Steelcase Inc. Company Information |author= |date= |work=hoovers.com |publisher=[[Hoover's]] |accessdate=7 November 2014}} It is the largest office furniture manufacturer in the world.{{cite news |title=World’s largest office furniture supplier celebrates 100 years by reducing its energy consumption and carbon footprint |author= |url=http://www.controleng.com/single-article/worlds-largest-office-furniture-supplier-celebrates-100-years-by-reducing-its-energy-consumption-and-carbon-footprint/6908c5217f65d70278c5a58a561e29b7.html |work=Control Engineering |date=February 14, 2013 |accessdate=5 December 2014}} The company has approximately 80 locations and 11,000 employees worldwide. Its locations include Global Business Centers in [[Mexico]], [[Malaysia]], and [[Romania]] that provide support to local Steelcase dealerships and offices; showrooms called WorkLife Centers across the United States, [[Europe]], and [[Asia]], and in [[Toronto]], [[Mexico City]], [[Sydney]], [[Melbourne]], and [[Dubai]]; and manufacturing facilities in [[North America]], Europe, the [[Middle East]], and Asia.{{cite news |title=Distributed But Not Distant: Bringing Remote Teammates to the Table |author= |url=http://360.steelcase.com/articles/distributed-but-not-distant-bringing-remote-teammates-to-the-table/ |work=360 Magazine |date= |accessdate=5 December 2014}} The company designs and produces furniture, [[Systems furniture|furniture systems]], [[Architecture|architectural]] products, [[textile]]s, wall surfaces, and [[Human factors and ergonomics|ergonomic]] and [[technology]] tools for workspaces, [[Higher education|education]], and [[Health care industry|health care]].{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/profiles/companies/SCS:US-steelcase-inc |title=Steelcase Inc |author= |date= |work=bloomberg.com |publisher=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |accessdate=7 November 2014}} Its products are sold online and through approximately 800 dealer locations. The company also offers workplace consulting services.{{cite news |title=How Steelcase is Rethinking the Workplace |author= |url=http://360.steelcase.com/articles/how-steelcase-is-rethinking-the-workplace/ |work=Steelcase 360 |date=2011 |accessdate=7 November 2014}} James Keane has served as [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] and president of the company since March 2014. The company's revenue equaled US$3 billion in 2014, an increase from $2.9 billion in 2013.{{cite web |url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/financials/financials.asp?ticker=SCS |title=Steelcase Inc-Cl A (SCS:New York) |date=November 7, 2014 |work=bloomberg.com |publisher=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |accessdate=7 November 2014}} Steelcase ranked 753 on the [[Fortune 1000]] list in 2014. ==Brands== The three main brands of Steelcase Inc. are Steelcase, [[Coalesse]], and [[Turnstone (company)|turnstone]]. The company also has several other brands and subsidiaries, including Designtex, [[PolyVision (Organization)|PolyVision]], and Steelcase Health and Education. Steelcase acquired Designtex in 1988. Designtex offers interior [[textile]]s and [[upholstery]].{{cite news |title=Steelcase Acquires N.Y. Fabric Firm |author=[[Associated Press]] |work=[[The Chicago Tribune]] |date=August 7, 1988 }} The company established its office accessories brand, Details, in 1990.{{cite news |title=The Human Touch: Manufacturers Discover That It Pays To Pay Attention To Workers Needs |author=Sharon Stangenes |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1990-06-24/news/9002210693_1_desks-steelcase-office-workers |work=[[The Chicago Tribune]] |date=June 24, 1990 |accessdate=7 November 2014}} In 1993, the company launched Turnstone, a line of furniture designed for [[small business]]es and [[Small office/home office|home offices]]. PolyVision was acquired in 2001 and makes light-weight [[ceramic]] steel surfaces used for writing, [[Projection screen|projection]], [[architecture]], and interiors.{{cite news |title=Steelcase Says It Is Buying PolyVision |author=[[Associated Press]] |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/aug/28/business/fi-39159 |work=[[The Los Angeles Times]] |date=August 28, 2001 |accessdate=7 November 2014}} In 2006, Nurture was founded to create products for the [[health care industry]], including furniture and interiors for waiting rooms, offices, and clinics.{{cite news |title=Steelcase's Medical Breakthrough |author=Reena Jana |url=http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2007-03-22/steelcases-medical-breakthroughbusinessweek-business-news-stock-market-and-financial-advice |work=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |date=March 22, 2007 |accessdate=7 November 2014}} The brand became Steelcase Health in 2014.{{cite news |title=Healthcare continues to drive markets |author=Karl D. Forth |url=http://www.cabinetmakerfdm.com/92389.html |work=CabinetMaker+FDM |date=July 7, 2014 |accessdate=7 November 2014}} Steelcase merged three of its subsidiaries, Brayton International, Metro Furniture and Vecta to form Coalesse in 2008. Coalesse products are meant for what the company calls "live/work” spaces, a result of the frequent overlap of home and office in modern working habits.{{cite news |title=Coalesse touts live and work environment |author=Jake Himmelspach |url=http://www.grbj.com/articles/print/70097 |work=[[Grand Rapids Business Journal]] |date=February 15, 2009 |accessdate=7 November 2014}} ==Company culture== [[Image:Steelcase Headquarters.jpg|thumb|274x274px|The WorkCafe in Steelcase Corporate Headquarters, [[Grand Rapids, Michigan]]]] In 1985, Steelcase purchased the [[Meyer May House]] designed by [[Frank Lloyd Wright]] and restored it, opening it to the public in 1987.{{cite news |title=Why Steelcase has long link to legendary architect Frank Lloyd Wright (Steelcase at 100) |author=Jim Harger |url=http://www.mlive.com/business/west-michigan/index.ssf/2012/03/steelcase_inc_adopts_frank_llo.html |work=[[MLive Media Group|MLive]] |date=March 16, 2012 |accessdate=7 November 2014}} A corporate art program has resulted in a collection including pieces by [[Pablo Picasso]], [[Andy Warhol]] and [[Dale Chihuly]].{{cite news |title=Steelcase: Designed For Durability |author=Rhonda Brammer |url=http://online.barrons.com/articles/SB923113334588747183?tesla=y |work=[[Barron's (newspaper)|Barron's]] |date=April 5, 1999 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}{{cite news |title=Work How You Want |author=Lindsey Howald Patton |url=http://gbdmagazine.com/2014/27-steelcase/ |work=Green Building and Design Magazine |date=May 2014 |accessdate=6 January 2015}} The company employs a research group called WorkSpace Futures to study workplace trends.{{cite news |title=Steelcase's Anthropologist on Remaking Offices to Create Happier Workers |author=Drake Baer |url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3004140/steelcases-anthropologist-remaking-offices-create-happier-workers |work=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]] |date=January 3, 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}} In 2010, Steelcase underwent a three-year project to update its Grand Rapids headquarters to promote employee productivity and [[Happiness at work|employee well-being]], including redesigning a cafeteria into an all-purpose work environment that provides food service and space for meetings, socializing, and independent work.{{cite news |title=Designing a Happier Workplace |author=Adam Piore |url=http://discovermagazine.com/2014/march/11-designing-a-happy-workplace |work=[[Discover (magazine)|Discover]] |date=March 2014 |accessdate=7 November 2014}}{{cite news |title=Some Companies Replace Cubicles With Flex Spaces |author=Fister Gale |url=http://www.workforce.com/articles/some-companies-replace-cubicles-with-flex-spaces |work=Workforce |date=May 30, 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}} Steelcase's sustainability efforts have included reducing packaging, using regional facilities to reduce shipping distance, cutting [[greenhouse gas]] emissions and water consumption, and a goal to reduce its [[Ecological footprint|environmental footprint]] by 25 percent by 2020.{{cite news |title=Steelcase Reduces GHG Emissions 49% Since 2001 |author= |url=http://www.environmentalleader.com/2009/07/22/steelcase-reduces-ghg-emissions-49-since-2001/ |work=Environmental Leader |date=July 22, 2009 |accessdate=11 October 2014}} As of 2012, Steelcase had reduced its waste by 80 percent, greenhouse gas emissions by 37 percent and water consumption by 54 percent since 2006.{{cite news |title=Steelcase details progress of sustainability efforts in new report |author=Mark Sanchez |url=http://mibiz.com/item/20584-steelcase-details-progress-of-sustainability-efforts-in-new-report#sthash.bTBddjrI.dpuf |work=MiBiz |date=April 28, 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}} According to the company's WorkFutures group, the company also analyzes its supply chain and materials chemistry to determine product sustainability. As of 2014, the company leads its industry in [[Cradle-to-cradle design|Cradle to Cradle-certified]] products. In 2016, Steelcase employees volunteered 38,913 hours and the Steelcase Foundation donated more than US$5.7 million.{{Cite news|url=https://www.steelcase.com/press-releases/steelcase-releases-2016-corporate-sustainability-report/|title=Steelcase Releases 2016 Corporate Sustainability Report - Steelcase|work=Steelcase|access-date=2017-08-17|language=en-US}} ==Noteworthy products== [[File:Leap-Chair.png|thumb|left|Leap chair]][[File:Gesture-Seating.png|thumb|right|Gesture seating]] Steelcase's most noteworthy products include "The Victor" wastebasket, a patented steel fireproof container released in 1914. The Victor became a top seller for the recently founded company and was eventually expanded into a line of products. The company released Multiple 15 desks in 1946, which introduced standardized desk sizing and became a universal industry standard. Series 9000 was released in 1973 and became Steelcase's most popular line of [[Systems furniture|office systems]]. The Leap chair, introduced in 1999, sold 5,000 units a week during its first year and became the company's most popular release. The [[Human factors and ergonomics|ergonomic]] office chair was designed with eight adjustable areas for users to control, including chair height, armrest positioning, lumbar support, seat depth, and back positioning. The chair was developed over four years, cost $35 million to design, and resulted in 11 academic studies and 23 patents.{{cite news |title=The Hot Seat |author=Bruce Sterling |url=http://archive.wired.com/wired/archive/8.07/chairs_pr.html |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |date=August 7, 2000 |accessdate=7 November 2014}} The company released the Gesture chair in 2013, which is designed to support the way workers naturally sit.{{cite news |title=Chair Pitched as Answer to New Ways We Sit on Job |author=David Pogue |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/12/technology/personaltech/a-good-office-chair-not-so-different-from-others.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 11, 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}} ==Awards== Steelcase was named among [[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune's]] most admired Home Equipment and Furnishings companies in 2011, 2012,{{cite news |title=Why Grand Rapids companies Spartan Stores, Steelcase made Fortune's 2012 'Most Admired' list |author=Shandra Martinez |url=http://www.mlive.com/business/west-michigan/index.ssf/2012/03/why_grand_rapids_companies_spa.html |work=[[MLive Media Group|MLive]] |date=March 21, 2012 |accessdate=7 November 2014}} 2013,{{cite news |title=Eight Michigan companies rank on Fortune's Most Admired list |author=Charlsie Dewey |url=http://www.grbj.com/articles/76347-eight-michigan-companies-rank-on-fortunes-most-admired-list |work=[[Grand Rapids Business Journal]] |date=March 11, 2013 |accessdate=7 November 2014}} and 2014.{{cite news |title=West Michigan companies rank among Fortune's 'Most Admired' |author=Rachel Weick |url=http://www.grbj.com/articles/79145-west-michigan-companies-rank-among-fortunes-most-admired |work=[[Grand Rapids Business Journal]] |date=March 5, 2014 |accessdate=7 November 2014}} The company won the Editors' Choice award at the 2014 NeoCon product competition for "Quiet Spaces," a series of workspaces designed for [[Extraversion and introversion|introverts]] and a collaboration with [[Susan Cain]], author of ''[[Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking]]''. In addition, Steelcase's SOTO II Worktools won a Silver Award in the Office Accessories category.{{cite news |title=NeoCon 2014: Steelcase wins Editors' Choice, Silver; work spaces unleash the power of introverts at work |author=Brianna Crandall |url=http://www.fmlink.com/article.cgi?type=News&archive=true&title=NeoCon%202014%3A%20Steelcase%20wins%20Editors%27%20Choice%2C%20Silver%3B%20work%20spaces%20unleash%20the%20power%20of%20introverts%20at%20work&mode=source&catid=124&display=article&id=46217 |work=FMLink |date=June 20, 2014 |accessdate=7 November 2014}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{official website|www.steelcase.com/}} [[Category:Furniture manufacturers]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies based in Michigan]] [[Category:Companies based in Grand Rapids, Michigan]] [[Category:Industrial design]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1912]] [[Category:1912 establishments in Michigan]] [[Category:Companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange]]

revision.comment: use patent as reference
revision.text:
{{primary sources|date=January 2015}} [[File:Super Bit Mapping (SBM) logo.gif|frame|right|Super Bit Mapping (SBM) logo.]] '''Super Bit Mapping''' ('''SBM''') is a [[noise shaping]] process, developed by [[Sony]] for [[Compact Disc|CD]] [[Audio mastering|mastering]].<ref>{{cite book |title= Digital audio technology: a guide to CD, MiniDisc, SACD, DVD(A), MP3 and DAT. |last1= Maes |first1= Jan |last2= Vercammen |first2= Marc |last3= Baert |first3= Luc |edition= 4th |year= 2001 |publisher= Focal Press |isbn= 978-0-240-51654-7 |pages= 60–63 }}</ref>
Sony claims that the Super Bit Mapping process converts a 20-[[bit]] signal from [[audio mastering|master recording]] into a 16-bit signal nearly without sound quality loss, using noise shaping to improve [[signal to noise ratio]] over the frequency bands most acutely perceived by human hearing.<ref>{{cite web |title=Super Bit Mapping Technical Overview |url=http://pdf.textfiles.com/manuals/STARINMANUALS/Sony%20Audio/Manuals/White%20Paper%20-%20Super%20Bit%20Mapping.pdf |publisher=Sony |accessdate=15 January 2013}}</ref>
Audible quantization error is reduced by [[noise shaping]] the error according to an [[equal-loudness contour]].<ref>{{cite patent |title=Quantizing error reducer for audio signal |country-code=US |patent-number=5204677}}</ref>
This processing takes place in dedicated hardware inside the recording device. A similar process is used in Sony's [[Direct Stream Digital|DSD]] to PCM conversion and is called SBM Direct.
==See also== * [[Extended Resolution Compact Disc]] * [[K2 High Definition]] * [[High Definition Compatible Digital]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Sound technology]] [[Category:Digital signal processing]]
{{Sound-tech-stub}}

revision.comment: /* History */ added link to wiki page on Embedded_C++
revision.text:
'''System programming''' (or '''systems programming''') is the activity of programming<ref name=":0" /> [[computer]] [[system software]]. The primary distinguishing characteristic of systems programming when compared to [[application programming]] is that application programming aims to produce software which provides services to the user directly (e.g. [[word processor]]), whereas systems programming aims to produce software and [[software platform]]s which provide services to other software, are performance constrained, or both (e.g. [[operating system]]s, [[computational science]] applications, [[game engine]]s and [[AAA (video game industry)|AAA video game]]s, [[Automation#Industrial automation|industrial automation]], and [[software as a service]] applications).<ref name=":0">{{cite web|title=Panel: Systems Programming in 2014 and Beyond|url=https://channel9.msdn.com/Events/Lang-NEXT/Lang-NEXT-2014/Panel-Systems-Programming-Languages-in-2014-and-Beyond|publisher=Microsoft|accessdate=4 December 2015}}</ref>
System programming requires a great degree of hardware awareness. Its goal is to achieve efficient use of available resources, either because the software itself is performance critical (AAA video games) or because even small efficiency improvements directly transform into significant monetary savings for the service provider (cloud based word processors).
== Overview ==
The following attributes characterize systems programming: * The [[programmer]] can make assumptions about the hardware and other properties of the system that the program runs on, and will often exploit those properties, for example by using an [[algorithm]] that is known to be efficient when used with specific hardware. * Usually a [[low-level programming language]] or programming language dialect is used so that: ** Programs can operate in resource-constrained environments ** Programs written to be efficient with little [[Run-time system|runtime]] overhead, they may have a small [[runtime library]], or none at all ** Programs may use direct and "raw" control over memory access and [[control flow]] ** The programmer may write parts of the program directly in [[assembly language]] * Often systems programs cannot be run in a [[debugger]]. Running the program in a [[computer simulation|simulated environment]] can sometimes be used to reduce this problem.
Systems programming is sufficiently different from application programming that programmers tend to specialize in one or the other.{{Citation needed|date=December 2015}}
In system programming, often limited programming facilities are available. The use of [[garbage collection (computer science)|automatic garbage collection]] is not common and [[debugging]] is sometimes hard to do. The [[runtime library]], if available at all, is usually far less powerful, and does less error checking. Because of those limitations, [[System monitoring|monitoring]] and [[data logging|logging]] are often used; [[operating system]]s may have extremely elaborate logging subsystems.
Implementing certain parts in operating systems and networking requires systems programming, for example implementing paging ([[virtual memory]]) or a [[device driver]] for an operating system.
== History == Originally systems programmers invariably wrote in [[assembly language]]. Experiments with hardware support in [[high level languages]] in the late 1960s led to such languages as [[IBM PL/S|PL/S]], [[BLISS]], [[BCPL]], and extended [[ALGOL]] for [[Burroughs large systems]]. [[Forth (programming language)|Forth]] also has applications as a systems language. In the 1980s, [[C (programming language)|C]] became ubiquitous, aided by the growth of [[Unix]]. More recently a subset of [[C++]] called [[Embedded C++]] has seen some use, for instance it is used in the [[I/O Kit]] drivers of [[macOS]].<ref>{{cite web|author1=Apple Inc|title=I/O Kit Device Driver Design Guidelines|url=https://developer.apple.com/library/mac/documentation/DeviceDrivers/Conceptual/WritingDeviceDriver/CPluPlusRuntime/CPlusPlusRuntime.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP30000695-BAJIBFDE|website=developer.apple.com|publisher=Apple Inc|accessdate=16 September 2014|date=14 August 2009}}</ref>
== Alternate usage == For historical reasons, some organizations use the term ''systems programmer'' to describe a job function which would be more accurately termed [[systems administrator]]. This is particularly true in organizations whose computer resources have historically been dominated by [[Mainframe computer|mainframe]]s, although the term is even used to describe job functions which do not involve mainframes. This usage arose because administration of [[IBM mainframes]] often involved the writing of custom [[assembler code]] ([[IBM Basic assembly language and successors|IBM's Basic Assembly Language]] (BAL)), which integrated with the [[operating system]] such as [[OS/MVS]], [[DOS/VSE]] or [[VM/CMS]]. Indeed, some [[IBM]] software products had substantial code contributions from customer programming staff. This type of programming is progressively less common, but the term ''systems programmer'' is still the de facto job title for staff directly administering IBM mainframes.
== See also == * [[Ousterhout's dichotomy]] * [[System programming language]] * [[Scripting language]] * [[Interrupt handler]]
== References == {{Reflist}} {{Refimprove|date=September 2014}}
==Further reading== * [https://catalog.loc.gov/vwebv/holdingsInfo?&bibId=4177732 Systems Programming] by [[John J. Donovan]]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:System Programming}} [[Category:Computer programming]] [[Category:System software]]

{{Infobox person | name = Takaaki Kidani | native_name = 木谷 高明 | native_name_lang = ja | image = Takaaki Kidani cropped 3 Suzuko Mimori and Takaaki Kidani 2010.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1960|06|06}} | birth_place = [[Kanazawa]], [[Ishikawa Prefecture|Ishikawa]], [[Japan]] | alma_mater = [[Musashi University]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|death date†|birth date†}} --> | death_place = | nationality = Japanese | other_names = | occupation = | known_for = }}
{{Nihongo|'''Takaaki Kidani'''|木谷 高明|Kidani Takaaki|born June 6, 1960}} is a Japanese businessman born in [[Kanazawa]], [[Japan]]. He is the founder and president of the [[Bushiroad]].<ref>{{Cite web| title = 木谷高明 初の著書「煽動者 ～徹底プロモーション 仕掛人の哲学～」| accessdate = 2014-08-01| url = http://hobbyjapan.co.jp/kidani/}}</ref> Kidani has also served as the chairman of [[New Japan Pro-Wrestling]] (NJPW). He continues to be involved with NJPW through Bushiroad, which owns the company.<ref>{{Cite web| title = 新日本プロレス木谷高明取締役会長が辞意を表明。「これからはブシロードグループとして外側からサポートして行く」| accessdate = 2017-01-19| url = http://www.njpw.co.jp/45498}}</ref>
== History == ===Early life=== After Kidani graduated from [[Musashi University]] with a degree in economics, he worked at [[Yamaichi Securities]]. He handled American duties.
===After the Establishment of Broccoli=== Kidani retired from [[Yamaichi Securities]] in 1994. In March 25 of the same year, he founded [[Broccoli (company)|Broccoli]] as a [[startup company]]. At first, his business focused on event management, but from 1994 to 1998, he started Comic Castle for [[dōjinshi]]. In 1996, he established his first chain of retail stores {{ill|Gamers Ltd.|lt=Gamers|ja|ゲーマーズ}}. His company has its center focus on anime and video games. Their company performance increased after producing the anime series [[Di Gi Charat]] and his company was then listed on the [[JASDAQ Securities Exchange]].
===After the Establishment of Bushiroad=== He founded Bushiroad in May 2007 as a company that produces card games and assumed the position of president. The origin of the name Bushiroad comes from the failure to make ''[[Neppu Kairiku Bushi Road]]'' into a film due to various reasons when he led the project in the days of Broccoli. The film was restarted in March 2013 with Kidani as the executive producer.
On October 2, 2017, Bushiroad announced that Kidani would be stepping down as the company's [[Representative Director (Japan)|Representative Director]] on October 20 and joining its [[board of directors]].<ref>{{cite web | url = https://bushiroad.co.jp/information/3 | title = 代表木谷の代表取締役退任について | date=2017-10-02 | accessdate=2017-10-04 | work=[[Bushiroad]] | language=Japanese}}</ref>
== Awards == *'''''[[List of Wrestling Observer Newsletter awards|Wrestling Observer Newsletter]]''''' **[[List of Wrestling Observer Newsletter awards#Promoter of the Year|Promoter of the Year]] (2014, 2017)<ref>{{cite magazine | last = Meltzer | first = Dave | authorlink = Dave Meltzer | date = January 26, 2015 | title = Jan. 26, 2015 Wrestling Observer Newsletter: 2014 awards issue w/ results & Dave’s commentary, Conor McGregor, and much more | magazine = [[Wrestling Observer Newsletter]] | location = [[Campbell, California]] | issn = 1083-9593 | page=33 | url=http://www.f4wonline.com/component/content/article/110-wrestling-observer-newsletter/40865-jan-26-2015-wrestling-observer-newsletter-2014-awards-issue-w-results-a-daves-commentary-conor-mcgregor-and-much-more}}</ref>
==References== <references /> {{commons category|Takaaki Kidani}} {{New Japan Pro Wrestling personnel}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kidani, Takaaki}} [[Category:Japanese business executives]] [[Category:Animation people]] [[Category:Professional wrestling executives]] [[Category:Game designers]] [[Category:People from Ishikawa Prefecture]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1960 births]]

revision.comment: Added as a Russell 2000 Component in the infobox
revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = TechTarget | logo = | type = [[Public company|Public]] | traded_as = {{NASDAQ|TTGT}}
[[Russell 2000 Index|Russell 2000 Component]] | industry = [[Marketing]] | foundation = 1999 | location = [[Newton, Massachusetts]] | key_people = | products = [[digital marketing]] | parent = | homepage = {{URL|https://www.techtarget.com}} }} '''TechTarget''' is an [[United States|American]] company which offers data-driven marketing services to business-to-business technology vendors. It uses purchase intent data gleaned from the readership of its 140 + technology focused web sites to help tech vendors reach buyers actively researching relevant IT products and services.{{Cite web|title=TTGT|url=http://www.nasdaq.com/symbol/ttgt|website=Nasdaq.com}} TechTarget, Inc. was founded in 1999 and is headquartered in [[Newton, Massachusetts]] with offices in Atlanta, London, Munich, Paris, San Francisco, Singapore and Sydney. == History == TechTarget was founded in 1999 by Greg Strakosch and Don Hawk as a spin-off of United Communications Group (UCG). In 2001, the company was recognized by B2B Magazine on the Media Power 50 list.[http://adage.com/article/btob/special-report-media-power-50/251894/ B2B Magazine on the Media Power 50 list] And in 2005, AdAge named CEO Greg Strakosch a Top 25 Newsmaker.[http://adage.com/article/btob/top-25-newsmakers/260789/ AdAge named CEO Greg Strakosch a Top 25 Newsmaker] In 2016, TechTarget named Michael Cotoia as CEO and board member, and elected Greg Stakosch as executive chairman.[https://www.martechadvisor.com/news/vendor-dataanalysis/techtarget-elects-mike-cotoia-as-ceo-and-board-member-greg-strakosch-as-executive-chairman/ TechTarget named Michael Cotoia as CEO and board member, and elected Greg Stakosch as executive chairman] The company had its [[initial public offering]] in May 2007, listing on the [[NASDAQ]] exchange with symbol TTGT.{{Cite web |title= Prospectus |date= May 16, 2007 |publisher= US Securities and Exchange Commission |url= https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1293282/000104746907004410/a2178038z424b4.htm |accessdate= November 7, 2016 }} Its current board of directors includes [[EMC Corporation]] founder [[Roger Marino]], [[Atlanta Hawks]] co-owner [[Bruce Levenson]], former CFO of the New York Times Co. [https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=995758&privcapId=428487 Leonard P. Forman], [https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=194593&privcapId=23267 Robert D. Burke], CEO Michael Cotoia and executive chairman Greg Strakosch. Since launch, the company has made several acquisitions aimed at building its technology content reach: In 2003, TechTarget acquired Information Security Magazine[http://adage.com/article/btob/techtarget-buys-information-security/256113/ acquired Information Security Magazine]. In 2004, the company acquired publications including: Bitpipe.com[https://www.bizjournals.com/boston/blog/mass-high-tech/2004/12/techtarget-takes-in-bostons-bitpipe-for-40m.html publications including: Bitpipe.com], TheServerSide.com and TheServerSide.net[https://www.bizjournals.com/boston/blog/mass-high-tech/2004/11/techtarget-takes-in-theserverside.html TheServerSide.com and TheServerSide.net]. In 2007 (the year the company went public), TechTarget acquired KnowledgeStorm for $58 million[http://www.dmnews.com/dataanalytics/techtarget-buys-knowledgestorm-for-58m/article/99016/ acquired KnowledgeStorm for $58 million]. In 2008, TechTarget acquired BrianMadden.com and BriForum.[http://www.cbsnews.com/news/techtarget-buys-brian-madden-company-adds-new-website-and-conference-to-roster/ BrianMadden.com and BriForum] The company acquired LeMagIT[https://finance.yahoo.com/news/techtarget-acquires-lemagit-211742431.html acquired LeMagIT] and opened local operations in France. In 2011, it made a significant acquisition[http://www.foliomag.com/techtarget-buys-rbis-computer-weekly-while-print-mag-folds/ significant acquisition] of Uk-based [[Computer Weekly]], which had been published as a weekly print magazine by [[Reed Business Information]] for more than 45 years. The company launched its current purchase intent data services (IT Deal Alert) for technology vendors in 2014 and has since added to the portfolio with a product called Priority Engine.[https://www.demandgenreport.com/features/news-briefs/techtarget-enhances-priority-engine-with-automated-target-profile-delivery Priority Engine] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * '''{{Official website|https://www.techtarget.com}}''' [[Category:Technology websites]] [[Category:Technology companies based in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Companies based in Middlesex County, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Newton, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Media companies established in 1999]] [[Category:Technology companies established in 1999]] [[Category:1999 establishments in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Companies listed on NASDAQ]] {{Ict-company-stub}}

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=September 2018}} The '''turn indicator stalk''' or '''turn signal lever''' is the control lever which operates the [[automotive lighting#Turn signals|turn signal or indicator lights]] on the front, sides and rear of the vehicle. It is usually operated by lifting or lowering the lever, the direction being commensurate with the clockwise or anticlockwise direction in which the steering wheel is about to be turned.
In [[right- and left-hand traffic|left hand drive]] (LHD) vehicles, the turn indicator stalks are usually located on the left of the steering column.
In right-hand-drive (RHD) [[motor vehicle]]s, the indicator stalk is located on either the left or right of the steering column, depending on the manufacturer. European RHD cars generally have the stalk on the left (often using the same component as LHD cars), while Asia-Pacific RHD cars generally have the stalk on the right (mirroring the configuration of a LHD vehicle). Some manufacturers such as [[Subaru]] still have variations in the model lineup as to where the turn indicator stalk is located.
==Innovations== Many other functions have been added to the turn signal stalk. Frequently headlamps and high beam controls are integrated into the turn signal control, the former requiring either a twisting motion or the use of a small switch, and the latter requiring movement of the control fore and aft.
Many modern cars have a "one-touch" feature on their stalks. This is primarily based on (motorway) lane-switching, where a single flick of the indicator will cause it to flash between two and six times.
Some cars have forgone the traditional stalk-mounted indicators for either a switch (as used on a [[motorcycle]]) or a button. Examples are the [[Caterham 7]] and the [[Ferrari 458]].
==See also== * [[Trafficator]]
==References== {{Footnotes}}

revision.text:
[[File:Biotech Place Night Image.jpg|thumb|Wake Forest Biotech Place]]'''Wake Forest Innovation Quarter''' in [[Winston-Salem, North Carolina]], is an innovation district focused on research, business and education in biomedical science, information technology, digital media, clinical services and advanced materials.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.journalnow.com/news/local/lofty-plans-take-shape-as-wake-forest-innovation-quarter-eyes/article_bc7d016f-7df6-5b7a-8f2e-76cd4d05c61e.html|title=Lofty plans take shape as Wake Forest Innovation Quarter eyes $1.7 billion public-private investment by 2030|last=Journal|first=Fran Daniel Winston-Salem|work=Winston-Salem Journal|access-date=2017-08-05|language=en}}</ref> The Innovation Quarter, operated by [[Wake Forest Baptist Medical Center]], is home to academic groups, private companies and other organizations located on 330 acres in downtown Winston-Salem. Its tenants include departments from five academic institutions—[[Wake Forest School of Medicine]], [[Wake Forest University]], [[Forsyth Technical Community College]], [[Winston-Salem State University]], [[University of North Carolina School of the Arts|UNC School of the Arts]]— as well as private businesses and other organizations. One tenant is the [[Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine]] (WFIRM), which is working to engineer more than 30 different replacement tissues and organs and to develop healing cell therapies.<ref name="WFIRM">{{cite web |url=http://www.WakeHealth.edu/WFIRM |title=Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine website}}</ref> The science and research conducted at WFIRM is behind two start-up companies at Innovation Quarter. The ability of researchers and scientists to work alongside entrepreneurs furthers a goal of Innovation Quarter to develop new treatments and cures for disease and advances in technology.
==History and Growth==
[[File:Wake Forest Innovations Lab Image.jpg|thumb]]The idea of a research park in Winston-Salem was a community-wide effort that began in the early 1990s in the wake of [[R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company]] closing many of its former downtown warehouse and manufacturing buildings. Wake Forest School of Medicine's Department of Physiology and Pharmacology moved into one former Reynolds warehouse in 1993, along with eight researchers from [[Winston-Salem State University]]. Civic committees and discussion led to a master plan being announced in 2002 for what was then called Piedmont Triad Research Park.
The first new building, One Technology Place, opened in 2000, occupied by Targacept Inc., a biopharmaceutical company that was spun out of R.J. Reynolds Tobacco. The company developed drugs to treat nervous system diseases and disorders.
Biotech Place opened in February 2012. The 242,000-square-foot structure is composed of two former Reynolds warehouses that have been renovated into a modern biotech research facility, with custom-designed wet and labs as well as Class A office space. The $100 million project was Winston-Salem's most expensive ever downtown project;<ref name=Downtown>{{cite web |url=http://www.journalnow.com/business/article_3efcc9f2-d3f7-52be-a565-e51fad10222d.html |title=Wake Forest Biotech Place debuts in downtown Winston-Salem}}</ref> it houses [[Wake Forest School of Medicine]]'s departments of Physiology and Pharmacology, Biomedical Engineering, and Immunology and Microbiology, as well as the Childress Institute for Pediatric Trauma. Private businesses—Carolina Liquid Chemistries, Allegacy Federal Credit Union, Brioche Doree cafe—also are tenants at Biotech Place.<ref name=Tenants>{{cite web |url=http://www.WakeForestInnovationQuarter.com/ |title=Wake Forest Innovation Quarter website}}</ref> Piedmont Triad Research Park was renamed in March 2013 as Wake Forest Innovation Quarter in recognition of the shift from biotechnology to a mix of biomedical and material sciences, information technology, and other health and communications fields.<ref name="Profile">{{cite web |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/triad/news/2013/03/11/now-wake-forest-innovation-quarter.html |title=As Wake Forest Innovation Quarter, research park hopes to raise profile}}</ref>
Early 2014 saw [https://www.inmar.com Inmar Inc., an information technology company], move into another renovated former R.J. Reynolds building in the Innovation Quarter. [https://www.inmar.com Inmar] relocated 900 employees from other sites in Winston-Salem to its new, state-of-the-art headquarters. The company also announced a partnership with the Division of Public Health Sciences of Wake Forest School of Medicine in which Inmar's digital analytics will be used to help locate and enroll patients for clinical trials conducted by the school. The Division of Public Health Sciences in early 2015 completed a move into the Innovation Quarter, in a building called 525@vine. The 525@vine building is adjacent to Inmar's headquarters. The 525@vine building, a five-story R.J. Reynolds factory built in 1926 and renovated in 2012-13, also houses the School of Medicine's Physician Assistant program, as well as Forsyth Technical Community College’s Emerging Technologies Center, which trains more than 1,200 students annually.<ref name=Inmar>{{cite news |url=http://www.journalnow.com/business/business_beat/inmar-marks-downtown-move-with-parade-celebration/article_b8a205a0-b906-11e3-9e89-001a4bcf6878.html?mode=story/html |title=Inmar marks downtown move with parade, celebration|work=Winston-Salem Journal}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.news-record.com/business/article_88a41839-33cf-5914-8b29-6294ab57f48b.html|title=525@vine officially opens in downtown research park|last=Daniel|first=Fran|work=Winston-Salem Journal|date=June 13, 2014|accessdate=June 14, 2014}}</ref>
==Public-Private Collaboration==
With state and federal funding, and the cooperation of neighboring communities, Innovation Quarter's expansion plan includes private businesses, retail and residential units. Among the work is relocating [[Norfolk Southern Railway|Norfolk Southern Railroad]] lines, construction of a new rail bridge and burying [[Duke Energy]] transmission lines. More than $17 million from the City of Winston-Salem and Forsyth County, have helped leverage $350 million in state, federal and private investment at Innovation Quarter.<ref name=Innovation>{{cite web |url=http://www.journalnow.com/business/business_news/local/article_41064d7e-8a6a-11e2-8655-0019bb30f31a.html |title=Research park renamed Wake Forest Innovation Quarter}}</ref>
==Wake Forest Innovations==
The renaming of Piedmont Triad Research Park to Wake Forest Innovation Quarter came shortly after Wake Forest Baptist Medical Center created a new operating division, Wake Forest Innovations, to establish and manage new business, partnerships, licenses and start-up companies based on the discoveries, intellectual property and research assets of the medical center and [[Wake Forest University]].
Wake Forest Innovations has separate units that market its scientific business assets-core laboratories, preclinical translational services, for example-to outside partners, while also promoting discovery and innovation and the licensing of technologies.<ref name="Profile" /> Wake Forest Innovation Quarter is another unit within Wake Forest Innovations.
